properties.media:imagetext:
(Family Letter No. 4)
Tokyo
Tuesday, February 7, 1950
Dear Family,
On Saturday, February 4 Amos Hiatt of PAA, who is
helping me on the Tokyo deal,
and
I drove
down to Kobe with -
of all
things
- two Turks.
An uncle and his nephew.
The
former hes a history which is tragic.
He was born in a little
town on the Amur River in Manchuria where his father was a
wealthy
merchant dealing
in wool and furs. In 1920 the Russian
Reds killed his father.
The mother escaped down the Amur in
a small boat with her eight children, was picked up at sea by
a Japanese gunboat and brought to Kobe.
There the children
got along on next to nothing but survived.
My friend went back
to Manchuria when he was eighteen and worked for his father's
old firm which had been
taken over by some Jews.
Later he went
into business for himself out in Sinkiang Province and ran a
fleet of
trucks along the old silk road from Peiping across
the Gobi Desert to Hami,
Turfan and throughout northwestern
China.
He made quite a fortune.
He had to drop everything
when
the Communists took over in China.
Now his wife is in
Peiping while he is staying in Kobe with his sister who is
married
to another wealthy Turk.
It was the sister's son who
drove the car
a Plymouth.
The boy is very good-looking.
has lived all his nineteen years in Japan -
speaks English like
an American and Japanese like a Japanese.
We started out at 5:00 a.m. in the dark,
Yokohama and going on to the Fugia Hotel at Menoshita
Leaving there we had our first view of Fuji which,
through the morning haze, looked as red as it is depicted on
the Japanese painted pillow covers which the sailors buy in
Later it was gold color.
We stopped at Lake Hakone
where our host, the uncle,
took some color films which I hope
to bring home
to show you all.
Vie drove all day through little
Japanese villages and open country over roads sometimes good
but often
in bad shape.
One flat tire tied us up in a little
town next to a
small
sawmill.
The owner brought us out three
chairs and we had lunch - beer,
sandwiches and fried chicken
which we had brought along - sitting in the lumber yard with a
beautiful view of nearby Fuji with a warm sun shining out of
a cloudless sky.
We drove on through Nagoya, Kyoto and Osaka -
all big cities - to Kobe where we arrived at 10:30 p.m. some
400 miles from Tokyo.
Our host's sister and husband have a large German-
style house on a hillside looking out over the city and bay.
The house is surrounded by a lovely Japanese garden.
The owner,
F. Gizatullin,
(pronounced like it is spelled)
and his wife
couldn't have been more cordial or hospitable.
They have five
other children besides Frederick (our chauffeur),
three girls
and two boys.
The children all speak English,
Turkish and
Japanese with equal facility but the father's English was not
